question: The basic empty mass of an aeroplane is recorded in:
optionA: the weighing schedule. If changes occur, due to modifications, the aeroplane must be re-weighed always.
optionB: the weighing schedule and is amended to take account of changes due to modifications of the aeroplane.
optionC: the loading manifest. It differs from dry operating mass by the value of the 'Traffic Load'.
optionD: the loading manifest. It differs from the zero fuel mass by the value of the 'Traffic Load'.

question: Usually in mass and balance calculations an index is used. The loaded index is:
optionA: a value of moment which is simplified and scaled down.
optionB: used in fuel density calculations and is called fuel-loading index.
optionC: used for ground handling purposes and is called wing-loading index.
optionD: called floor-loading index and it is used to simplify the loading of an aircraft.

question:
Given the following information at take-off:

ITEM MASS ARM MOMENT
(kg) (cm) (kgcm)
Basic Empty Condition 12045 +30 +361350
Crew 145 -160 -23200
Freight 1 570 +200 +114000
Freight 2 410 -40 -16400
Fuel 6045 -8 -48360

Flight time: 2 hrs
Estimated fuel flow: 1.050 l/hr
Fuel density: 0.79 kg/l

The "Freight 2" will be dropped during flight within the scope of a rescue action. Calculate the CG position at landing.
In mass and balance calculations the "index" is:
optionA: is a figure without unit of measurement which represents a moment.
optionB: an imaginary vertical plane or line from which all measurements are taken.
optionC: the range of moments the centre of gravity (CG) can have without making the aeroplane unsafe to fly.
optionD: a location in the aeroplane identified by a number.

question: The principle of the index method is:
optionA: to divide high magnitude moments by a constant and thereby simplify calculations by decreased values.
optionB: to round all values for easier and much faster calculation.
optionC: to refer all the items of an aircraft to a position which is called BA (Balance Arm).
optionD: to calculate the centre of gravity position (CG) and stabiliser trim setting without calculating the load sheet.

question: What is the DOI?
optionA: The index for the position of the centre of gravity at dry operating mass.
optionB: The index for the position of the centre of pressure at any mass.
optionC: The index for the position of the centre of gravity when dropping cargo during flight.
optionD: The index for the position of the centre of gravity at operating mass.

question:
Given the following information, calculate the loaded centre of gravity (CG).

STATION
Basic Empty Mass
Mass (kg): 12045
Arm (cm): +30
Moment (kgcm): +361350

Crew
Mass (kg): 145
Arm (cm): +160
Moment (kgcm): -23200

Freight 1
Mass (kg): 5455
Arm (cm): +200
Moment (kgcm): +1109100

Freight 2
Mass (kg): 410
Arm (cm): -40
Moment (kgcm): -16400

Fuel
Mass (kg): 6045
Arm (cm): -8
Moment (kgcm): -48360

Additional equipment for the mission
Mass (kg): 124
Arm (cm): +40
Moment (kgcm): +4960
The method of using indexes in mass and balance calculations is used to:
optionA: decrease the magnitude of the useful load.
optionB: increase the magnitude of the useful load.
optionC: decrease the magnitude of the moments.
optionD: increase the magnitude of the moments.

question: State the advantage(s) of the index method to determine moments:
optionA: it reduces the dimensions of the moments thus making it easier to calculate.
optionB: it directly produces the centre of gravity position (CG) and the stabiliser trim setting.
optionC: it enables the pilots to calculate the centre of gravity position (CG) by mental arithmetic and thereby expedites mass and balance calculations.
optionD: it is a digital system and can be used to automatically upload data to the aircraft flight management computer (FMC) for determining the stabiliser trim setting.

The aft centre of gravity limit is located at 2.97 m. The datum is located in front of the aircraft. Is it allowed to fly under otherwise identical conditions if a pilot is weighing 10 kg less as given?
optionA: No, the new centre of gravity is located 1 cm aft of the aft limit, thus outside the allowable range.
optionB: Yes, the new centre of gravity is now located more forward within the allowable range.
optionC: Yes, the new centre of gravity is located 1 cm forward of the aft limit, thus still within the allowable range.
optionD: Yes, the reduced mass can only have a positive effect

optionC: The documentation is not signed prior to flight.
optionD: Acceptable last minute changes to the load must be documented.

question:
Given:

Total Mass: 2900 kg
Centre of gravity (CG) location: 115.0
Aft CG limit station: 116.0

The maximum mass that can be added at station 130.0 is:

Given:
Actual mass: 116500 lbs
Original CG station: 435.0
Compartment A station: 285.5
Compartment B station: 792.5
If 390 lbs of cargo is moved from compartment B (aft) to compartment A (forward), what is the station number of the new CG?

Total Mass: 7500 kg
Centre of gravity (CG) location station: 80.5
Aft CG limit station: 79.5
How much cargo must be shifted from the aft cargo compartment at station 150 to the forward cargo compartment at station 30 in order to move the CG location to the aft limit?

An aeroplane, whose specific data is shown in the annex, has a planned Take-off Mass of 200,000 kg, with its centre of gravity (CG) is located at 15.38 m rearward of the reference point, representing a CG location at 30% MAC (Mean Aerodynamic Chord). For performance purposes, the captain decides to reset the value of the centre of gravity location to 35% MAC. The front and rear cargo compartments are located at a distance of 15 m and 25 m from the reference point respectively, the cargo load mass which needs to be transferred from the front to the rear cargo compartment is:
optionA: It is not possible to establish the required centre of gravity location.

question: The loaded mass of an aircraft is 2000 kg. What is the movement of the CG if additional 400 kg of cargo is loaded to a hold 2 m aft of the present CG position?

The Total Mass of an aeroplane is 9 000 kg. The centre of gravity (CG) position is at 2.0 m from the datum line. The aft limit for CG is at 2.1 m from the datum line. What mass of cargo must be shifted from the front cargo hold (at 0.8 m from the datum) to the aft hold (at 3.8 m), to move the CG to the aft limit?

The planned Take-off Mass of a turbojet aeroplane is 180 000 kg, with its centre of gravity located at 26% MAC (Mean Aerodynamic Chord). Shortly prior to engine start, the local staff informs the flight crew that 4 000 kg must be unloaded from cargo 4 (23.69 m aft of reference point). Given:
Distance from reference point to leading edge: 14 m
Length of MAC: 4.6 m
After the handling operation, the new centre of gravity location in % MAC will be?

Length of the Mean Aerodynamic Chord: 1 m
Moment Arm of the forward cargo: -0.50 m
Moment Arm of the aft cargo: +2.50 m
Aircraft mass: 2200 kg
Centre of gravity: 25% MAC
To move the centre of gravity to 40%, which mass has to be transferred from the forward to the aft cargo hold?

Given:

Aeroplane mass = 36 000 kg
Centre of gravity (CG) is located at station 17 m

What is the effect on CG location if you move 20 passengers (Total Mass = 1 600 kg) from station 16 to station 23?

A planned Take-off Mass of 200 000 kg; with its centre of gravity (CG) located at 15.38 m rearward of the reference point; representing a CG location at 30% MAC (Mean Aerodynamic Chord). The current cargo load distribution is: Front cargo: 6 500 kg Rear cargo: 4 000 kg. For performance purposes, the captain decides to reset the value of the centre of gravity location to 33% MAC. The front and rear cargo compartments are located at a distance of 15 m and 25 m from the reference point respectively. After the transfer operation, the new cargo load distribution is:
optionA: front cargo: 9 260 kg; rear cargo: 1 240 kg.
optionB: front cargo: 3 740 kg; rear cargo: 6 760 kg.
optionC: front cargo: 6 760 kg; rear cargo: 3 740 kg.
optionD: front cargo: 4 550 kg; rear cargo: 5 950 kg.

A jet aeroplane, with the geometrical characteristics shown in the appendix, has a take-off weight (W) of 460 000 N and a centre of gravity (point G on annex) located at 15.40 m from the zero reference point. At the last moment the station manager has 12 000 N of freight added in the forward compartment at 10 m from the zero reference point. The final location of the centre of gravity, calculated in percentage of Mean Aerodynamic Chord AB (from point A), is equal to:
Rush bags, last minute baggage and cabin crew baggage is held in/on:
Which of the listed types of cargo can most likely be found in a bulk cargo compartment?
Passenger baggage of an aircraft is usually stored:
optionA: on the aircraft floor and secured with nets.

question: Which of the following statements about loading is correct?
optionA: Bulk cargo loading requires much less ground personal than the loading of containers.
optionB: Live animals are never loaded as bulk cargo.
optionC: Containers can be connected directly to the aircraft and each container has its own manifest.
optionD: Pallets are mainly used on small aircraft and are strapped down.

question: Imagine some large transport aircraft (e.g. Airbus A340, A380 or Boeing 747) which is flying from London to New York. The passengers personal belongings should be placed:
optionA: as baggage in special cargo containers.
optionB: overhead the occupant's seats compartments, so they are easily accessible during flight.
optionC: underneath as bulk cargo, in order to minimize the space required.
optionD: on cargo pallets, safely tied by nets.

question: Which statement about palletised cargo is true?
optionA: It can be loaded without any specific loading equipment.
optionB: It comprises passenger baggage on pallets which is stored in cargo holds.
optionC: It consists of individual or multiple items stored on pallets and secured with nets and/or straps.
optionD: It is not used anymore because of the lack of protection.

question: The floor limit of an aircraft cargo hold is 5 000 N/mÂ². It is planned to load-up a cubic container measuring 0.4 m of side. It's maximum gross mass must not exceed (assume g = 10 m/sÂ²):
The structural limitation of a baggage compartment is 50 lb/ftÂ². A load has a mass of 320 kg and has to be distributed over an area of at least:

The maximum floor loading for a cargo compartment in an aeroplane is given as 750 kg per square metre. A package with a mass of 600 kg is to be loaded. Assuming the pallet base is entirely in contact with the floor, which of the following is the minimum size pallet that can be used?

Given:
Pallet: 1.2 x 1.2 m
Max. running load: 1915 lb/m

Find the maximum allowed mass which can be loaded on the pallet without exceeding the maximum running load.

The maximum intensity floor loading for an aeroplane is given in the Flight Manual as 650 kg per square metre. What is the maximum mass of a package which can be safely supported on a pallet with dimensions of 80 cm by 80 cm?

Refer to figure 031-19 A pallet having a freight platform which measures 200 cm x 250 cm has a Total Mass of 300 kg. The pallet is carried on two ground supports each measuring 20 cm x 200 cm. Using the Loading Manual for the transport aeroplane, calculate how much mass may be added to, or must be off loaded from, the pallet in order for the load intensity to match the maximum permitted distribution load intensity for lower deck forward cargo compartment.

The maximum load per running metre of an aeroplane is 350 kg/m. The width of the floor area is 2 metres. The floor strength limitation is 300 kg per square metre. Which one of the following crates can be loaded directly on the floor?
optionA: A load of 700 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.8 m x 1.4 m x 0.8 m.
optionB: A load of 500 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.5 m x 1 m x 1 m.
optionC: A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.4 m x 0.8 m x 0.8 m.
optionD: A load of 400 kg in a crate with dimensions 1.2 m x 1.2 m x 1.2 m.

question: Loads must be adequately secured in order to:
optionA: avoid any centre of gravity (CG) movement during flight.
optionC: prevent excessive g-loading during the landing flare.
optionD: avoid unplanned centre of gravity (CG) movement and aircraft damage.
